advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>From the magazine 'Micro Sistemas' of March 1983 <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.mci.org.br </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Laser 3000. For 5980F, play the double compatibility !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRAPPING MAN!</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> A compact problem-solving add for engineers, statisticians, scientists and financial and business analysts. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER TERMINAL TO NETWORK STATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HiNet local network system allowed data to be transfered at a 256 Kbyte/sec. speed. It was able to run under CP/M or MS/DOS operating systems. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to datareign.co.uk for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 816/C VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 816/C version was a multi-user system featuring:<br> - Dual CPU (8085 + 8088) motherboard<br> - 384 KB of RAM, expandable to 1 MB<br> - 2 x 1.2 MB 8" F.D. drives<br> - 9 serial ports<br> - 3 to 16 users expansion<br><br> As the magazine 'computer Age' said, this system was almost twice as quick as an IBM-PC. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> POWER... IS EXPENSIVE!</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Megabyte Micro was a special version of the Imsai made with 16 x 64 KB RAM boards (Imsai just introduced this card) and a control board called Intelligent Memory Manager. A mapping configurator allowed each user to use its own protected RAM area. <br><br> Prices :<br><br> 64 KB RAM board Kit: <b>$2599</b>, assembled: <b>$3899</b><br> Intelligent Memory Manager board: <b>$299</b>, assembled: <b>$399</b><br><br> To note: in 1977, 1 MB RAM costed... $62384!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>He is rich (enough to buy a LISA !), he is relaxed... He is the typical advertising executive of the 80's.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOL PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><u>Sol Systems price list (january 1977)</u></b> <br><br> (K) = Kit (A) = Assembled<br><br> <b>Sol Terminal Computers<br> </b>SOL-PC Single board (K) <b> $475</b><br> SOL-10 (K) <b> $795</b><br> SOL-20 (K) <b> $995</b> <br><br> <b>Memory Modules</b> <br> PROM Resident Assembly Language (A) <b>$425</b><br> Interpretive Simulator (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Text Editing (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Erasable PROM module (K) <b>$65 </b>(A) <b>$89</b> <br> 4 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b> $159</b> (A) <b> $195</b><br> 8 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b>$295</b> (A) <b>$375</b><br> 16 Kb. Dynamic Ram (A) <b>$529</b> <br><br> <b>Interface Modules</b><br> Parallel / Serial I/O Module (K) <b>$149</b> (A) <b>$199</b><br> System cassette interface (K) <b>$87 </b> (A) <b>$119</b><br> Video Display Module (K) <b>$199 </b> (A) <b>$295</b><br> <br> <b>Mass Storage System</b><br> Helios II Disk system (K) <b>$1895</b> (A) <b>$2295</b><br><br> <b>Software<br> </b>(C) = Cassette (P) = Paper tape<br> Basic 5 (P) <b>$19.95</b><br> 8K Basic (C) <b>$29</b> (P) <b>$37</b><br> New 8080 Focal (C) <b>$14.50</b> <br> Trek 80 Video game (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> GamePack 1 (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> MathPack Video calculator (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> Assembler (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> ALS 8 (C) <b>$35</b> (P) <b>$45</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA 1 PIN</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOGS (1993)</strong></font><br><blockquote>WP-3 model</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was used to promote the educative potential of the TO-7/70. This poor student is studying economic politics... <br><br> As usual, no cables are shown... the tape recorder is thus useless... Will someone tell him ?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert price list:<br><br> 16K RAM: <b>$399</b> (kit) <b>$459</b> (assembled)<br> Parity option: <b>$39</b> (kit) <b>$59</b> (assembled)<br> Floating point board: <b>$259</b> (kit) <b>$359</b> (assembled)<br> Z80 board: <b>$199</b> (kit) <b>$259</b> (assembled)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2D ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Z-2D 1977 price list:<br><br> - Kit version with 1 F.D. drive: <b>$1495</b><br> - Assembled version: <b>$2095</b><br> - Additional F.D. drive: <b>$495</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The successor of the JR 200. Almost everything was changed, the computer has two CPUs to keep the compatibility with the previous models (JR-200). This machine has also a superimposition feature.
In fact it seems to be a mix between a JR-200 and a Sharp X1 system... quite strange ! But apparently this model was never really marketed.
A handheld model called JR 800 was launched few time later, but it was not compatible with the previous JR computers.
computer.keyboard: Full stroke keyboard, 98 keys, 6 function keys, separated numeric keypad
computer.name: National JR 300
computer.peripherals: JR-F01 5''1/4 disk units, JR-F02 additional disk-drive, JR-F03 3''1/2 disk-drives, JR-F04 additional 3''1/2 diks-drive, JR-P01 Graphic printer, RQ-8300 & RQ-8200 tape-recorders
computer.ports: RGB video output, Monitor, Audio out, Expansion, Tape (600/2400 bauds), Centronics, Joysticks,
